<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 275, 324, 292]]<|/det|>
## FURTHER MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 276, 905, 291]]<|/det|>
9231/12  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 368, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Further Pure Mathematics 1  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[707, 301, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
October/November 2024  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 325, 905, 340]]<|/det|>
2 hours  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 370]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 393, 400]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 419, 222, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 868, 638]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 666, 212, 680]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 682, 728, 713]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 75.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[71, 72, 87, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 728, 92]]<|/det|>
The sequence \(u_{1}, u_{2}, u_{3}, \ldots\) is such that \(u_{1} = 4\) and \(u_{n + 1} = 3u_{n} - 2\) for \(n \geqslant 1\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 598, 122]]<|/det|>
Prove by induction that \(u_{n} = 3^{n} + 1\) for all positive integers \(n\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 102, 917, 121]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 500, 91]]<|/det|>
The line \(l_{2}\) is parallel to the vector \(5\mathbf{i} - 5\mathbf{j} - 2\mathbf{k}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 104, 148, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 103, 467, 121]]<|/det|>
Find the acute angle between \(l_{2}\) and \(\varPi\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 103, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 234, 88]]<|/det|>
It is given that

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[410, 97, 589, 156]]<|/det|>
\[\begin{array}{c}\alpha +\beta +\gamma +\delta = 2,\\ \alpha^{2} + \beta^{2} + \gamma^{2} + \delta^{2} = 3,\\ \alpha^{3} + \beta^{3} + \gamma^{3} + \delta^{3} = 4. \end{array}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 180, 146, 199]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 180, 536, 199]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(\alpha \beta + \alpha \gamma + \alpha \delta + \beta \gamma + \beta \delta + \gamma \delta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 180, 920, 199]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 458, 143, 477]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 458, 920, 477]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(\alpha^{2}\beta +\alpha^{2}\gamma +\alpha^{2}\delta +\beta^{2}\alpha +\beta^{2}\gamma +\beta^{2}\delta +\gamma^{2}\alpha +\gamma^{2}\beta +\gamma^{2}\delta +\delta^{2}\alpha +\delta^{2}\beta +\delta^{2}\gamma .\) [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 71, 94, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 415, 88]]<|/det|>
The matrices \(\mathbf{A}, \mathbf{B}\) and \(\mathbf{C}\) are given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[303, 97, 700, 153]]<|/det|>
\[\mathbf{A} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 & 3 \\ 2 & 1 & 3 \\ 3 & 2 & 5 \end{pmatrix}, \mathbf{B} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & -2 \\ -1 & 3 \\ 0 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \text{and} \mathbf{C} = \begin{pmatrix} -2 & -1 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & 3 \end{pmatrix}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 176, 146, 196]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 170, 391, 203]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\mathbf{CAB} = \begin{pmatrix} 3 & -7 \\ -9 & 3 \end{pmatrix}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 178, 920, 197]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 470, 186, 489]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 470, 920, 508]]<|/det|>
Find the equations of the invariant lines, through the origin, of the transformation in the \(x\)-\(y\) plane represented by \(\mathbf{CAB}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 490, 920, 508]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 255, 109]]<|/det|>
Let \(\mathbf{M} = \begin{pmatrix} 3 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 131, 144, 149]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 129, 599, 149]]<|/det|>
Give full details of the transformation represented by \(\mathbf{M}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 131, 920, 149]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 317, 148, 335]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 317, 485, 335]]<|/det|>
Find the matrix \(\mathbf{N}\) such that \(\mathbf{N}\mathbf{M} = \mathbf{C}\mathbf{A}\mathbf{B}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 317, 920, 335]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 119]]<|/det|>
Given instead that \(\mathrm{f}(r) = 2\log_{r}r\) where \(x\neq 1\), use standard results from the List of formulae (MF19) to find \(\sum_{n = 1}^{N}S_{n}\) in terms of \(N\). Fully factorise your answer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 97, 920, 115]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 79, 94, 100]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 416, 107]]<|/det|>
The curve \(C\) has equation \(y = \frac{x^2 + 3}{x^2 + 1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 112, 146, 131]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 112, 863, 134]]<|/det|>
Show that \(C\) has no vertical asymptotes and state the equation of the horizontal asymptote. [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 268, 146, 286]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 268, 500, 287]]<|/det|>
Show that \(1 < y \leqslant 3\) for all real values of \(x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 268, 918, 287]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 625, 181, 644]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 625, 552, 644]]<|/det|>
Find the coordinates of any stationary points on \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 636, 917, 655]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 71, 920, 91]]<|/det|>
Sketch \(C\), stating the coordinates of any intersections with the axes and labelling the asymptote.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 87, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 361, 176, 380]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[178, 351, 920, 388]]<|/det|>
Sketch the curve with equation \(y = \frac{x^{2} + 1}{x^{2} + 3}\) and find the set of values of \(x\) for which \(\frac{x^{2} + 1}{x^{2} + 3} < \frac{1}{2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 384, 920, 403]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 918, 96]]<|/det|>
The curve \(C_{1}\) has polar equation \(r = a(\cos \theta + \sin \theta)\) for \(- \frac{1}{4}\pi \leqslant \theta \leqslant \frac{3}{4}\pi\) , where \(a\) is a positive constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 107, 146, 125]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 107, 920, 141]]<|/det|>
Find a Cartesian equation for \(C_{1}\) and show that it represents a circle, stating its radius and the Cartesian coordinates of its centre.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 121, 920, 140]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 492, 720, 512]]<|/det|>
Sketch \(C_{1}\) and state the greatest distance of a point on \(C_{1}\) from the pole.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 492, 920, 512]]<|/det|>
